units.text: Summary:

Today, the use of social media websites such as Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and TikTok has become the norm for online communication with friends, family, and acquaintances. While such sites help people keep in touch, they also pose a great risk to personal identifiable information (PII). In order to protect this PII, users must think of confidentiality, availability, and trust (or the CAT model) before making posts on a social networking website like Facebook or Twitter.
Description

The use of all social networking websites revolve around one main activity-- posting information about yourself. While sharing information about yourself can be fun, you always run the risk of sharing it with someone you didn't want to; this is the real danger of using social networking websites like Facebook or Twitter.
Risk - How Can It Happen?

Posting online without first weighing the consequences or taking precautions to ensure that your information is safe is a practice that can get any user in trouble. It is important that before you make any post, you consider the privacy of your post, the lifetime of your post, and the audience your post will reach. These three considerations are the CAT model: Confidentiality (How private your posts are), Availability (How long your posts are accessible), and Trust (who you're trusting with your posts). Posting carelessly without taking these issues into consideration can be a risky practice that can lead to trouble for you now or down the road in your career.
Example of Occurence
A woman working as a teacher's aide made a post on Facebook out of frustration towards the kids she worked with, and later got fired for her behavior.
Source: http://www.newson6.com/story/23547100/concho-teachers-aide-fired-over-facebook-post
Answer the following questions:

units.prompt: The CAT model helps protect information you post from being seen by an inappropriate audience.
What considerations are associated with the CAT model?

units.text: In order to avoid privacy issues, it is important to take CAT, or Confidentiality, Availability, and Trust into consideration. Below is a brief description of each:
Confidentiality
Confidentiality answers the question "how private are my posts?" The confidentiality of your posts can be analyzed by completing a few steps:

a. Read the Privacy Policy. While many of these can be long and tedious reads, if you are planning on disclosing information you might not want to be seen by the public, it is important to at least get a general idea of your rights and privileges when using these sites. These are subject to change, so make sure that you keep an eye on and updates the company may announce.

b. Check your settings! Before you post any information on an account, check to see who will be able to see the posts you make. Most sites give you the ability to control who, or what groups you want to allow access to your profile. Remember, default settings are not always enough!

c. View your public profile. One of the best ways to make sure your information is safe from the public is by checking it yourself. Simply sign out of your account and check your profile URL. This will show you exactly what the public can see, and help you decide what settings to change.

d. Think of your four audiences. When posting to a profile, think about what permissions you have given each of these four audiences: friends, family, potential employers, and public. Consider who you want to see the post vs. who might see it.
Availability

Availability answers the question "how long is my information accessible?" In order to determine the availability of posts or information you post on a social networking website, the following steps can be taken:

a. Keep different accounts for different purposes. It’s likely you don’t want to let your boss see that picture of you at that party last weekend that your friend posted on Facebook. At the same time, you want potential employees to be able to get a basic idea of who you are through an online profile. Keep different accounts for different purposes; save Facebook for your friends, and keep a professional, public account on another site like LinkedIn. This will help you balance work and social life, while keeping information available for each audience.
b. Take advantage of settings controlling availability. The settings on social networking websites are getting more advanced. Look into some of the controls available to you and utilize them.

c. Clean your profile. A very simple way to control the availability of information on your profile is by systematically going through your account to make sure all information is appropriate. Schedule an hour or so each month to go through your posts and delete anything that you may not want to be available.
Trust

Trust answers the question "who am I trusting with my information?" The people you trust are the people who you allow to see your information and posts. To analyze the security of the trust you have, you can take the following steps:

a. Pay attention to who you ‘friend’. When adding friends, you’re giving them permission to access personal data you have posted on your account. Are you going to connect with strangers you’ve never met before, on an account that gives all your personal details? Your boss may want to be friends on Facebook, but is it appropriate to entwine your social life with your work life? These are all aspects you will have to consider when choosing to allow different people access to your profile.

b. Watch friends’ online habits. On websites like Facebook, users have the ability to play games. Often, these applications request access to personal information. However, some applications ask to access their friends’ personal data as well. This is why it is important to keep an eye on your friend’s online habits and check to see what permissions they are giving applications.

c. Be aware of who you share your profile with. On some social networking accounts, your account doesn’t use your name, only a username. These profiles give you the ability to pick and choose who knows about the account. It is important that when you are giving your username to someone to look up, they fit into the proper audience for that given profile.

units.text: For this assignment, you will be working in partners. It is important that you are not friends with this partner on any social media website. Both partners should have accounts on Facebook and Twitter. Introduce yourselves and log on to your computers.In order to complete this lab, each partner will plant two ‘flags’ for the other partner to try and find through social networking. On your Twitter account, post your favorite movie title. On your Facebook account, post your favorite color.

items: Can you see where they are currently living? Working?
Can you see their phone number?
Can you look at photos/videos of them?
